title: Ofcom To Revive Prospect Of BT Group Break-Up
text:
View Photo 

The communications regulator will on Thursday reignite the debate about the future of BT's infrastructure arm‎ by floating the prospect of its physical separation as part of a wider review of digital communications. 
‎Sky News understands that Ofcom will seek views about the impact of BT hiving off Openreach, the unit which manages access to the national telecoms network. 
The idea will be one of many raised in Ofcom's Di‎gital Communications Review, and will not amount to a proposal or recommendation in what people close to the work said would be a discussion paper. 
The regulator last examined the possibility of Openreach's separation several years ago, and BT has persistently rejected arguments from rivals that relinquishing its ownership of the division would boost competition in the telecoms and broadband markets. 
Ofcom's paper will also call for views about retaining the status quo as well as revising undertaking commitments from BT in relation to Openreach.‎ 
BT competes with Sky (Other OTC: BSYBF - news ) , the owner of Sky News, in areas including broadband and the provision of pay-television services.‎ 
Ofcom does not have the power to enforce a separation of ‎Openreach, but could refer it to the Competition and Markets Authority - a move for which Sky publicly called last month. 
Other major broadband providers have urged regulators to break up BT, arguing that it uses its ownership of Openreach to aid its retail business at the expense of rivals. 
BT rejects this suggestion, saying that its multibillion pound investment programme has only been possible because of its group structure. 
"The payback for a separate network company would be in the region of 20 years and would be far too risky," a person close to the company said. 
Ofcom is expected to make formal recommendations towards the end of the year.‎ 
It declined to comment on Wednesday on the contents of the discussion paper or on the length of the forthcoming consultation period.‎
